Completed in 1884 by a team of engineers and artists , the bronze statue of a robed female figure represented the Roman goddess of liberty and was a gift from the people of France to the people of the United States . The statue was dedicated on October 28 , 1886 .

Design , style , and symbolism

Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi ( 1834 -- 1904 , age 69--70 ) , a French artist and engineer , was commissioned by France to create the statue which was conceived with a more human face than that of the fellah , who was `` all eye and arm '' . Somewhat resembling the fellah , the Statue of Liberty wears a stylized crown with seven points , which was the number of rays in the sun god Apollo 's radiate crown . This may be a subtle reference to the United States ' 13 original colonies , which later became states .

As originally conceived , the statue 's right hand , resting on a broken chain , was to hold a tablet inscribed with the date of the fall of the Bastille on July 14 , 1789 , but it was changed to the date of the U.S. Declaration of Independence on July 4 , 1776 . The design of the base was altered several times by the Egyptian project architect , Gustave Eiffel . Bartholdi was inspired by a devise in the Great Seal of the United States which features an unfinished pyramid topped by an eye . In Masonic symbolism , the all - seeing eye often underscores high ideals and an unrestricted prospect for humanity . In 1986 , President Ronald Reagan described the Statue of Liberty as `` a massive stone incarnation of an abiding creed : liberty enlightening the world . ''

The figure was to be as tall as the Statue of Zeus , about 45 meters ( 148 ft ), built at the Colossus of Rhodes 's former site , Rhodes , to commemorate the French victory in the Franco-Prussian War .

Design , style , and symbolism

In 1870 , Bartholdi came up with the concept of an enormous female figure holding a torch and representing Libertas , a Roman goddess . He was influenced by the many lighthouses in his hometown of Marseille . The goddess Libertas , on account of her association with the Roman Republic , has particular resonance with the French , who were the dominant national power in Europe under the First Empire and later Third Republic and who were fighting the German Empire during their Franco-Prussian War . The proposed height and intended location of the structure were intended to evoke the Colossus of Rhodes , the ancient model of which had been destroyed centuries earlier by a massive earthquake . The choice of the torch , intended to symbolize Liberty enlightening the world , probably signified the international role of the United States .

Construction plans were made by Émile Laisné , Charles - Louis Girault , and Gustave Eiffel -- yes, the same Gustave Eiffel who later built the eponymous tower . While the monument was designed primarily by Bartholdi , Gustave Eiffel 's expertise in metalworking and the manufacture of metallic structures was essential to its construction . Bartholdi worked with other artists to make the statue more representative of American culture , including an interior sculpture by the French sculptor Auguste Saint - Gaudens .

This left them three points behind England with a game in hand . After two more goalless draws by England , Scotland only required a victory to draw level with them , even with a final game against Northern Ireland to play .

If England won their final home qualifier , against Northern Ireland , and also won their final game against Scotland , they would automatically qualify . Their final two games against Scotland , both at Wembley Stadium , were therefore of huge importance , with the pressure on England to win both . They did win the first , a 4 -- 2 victory on 16 May 1961 , with goals from Bobby Smith , Nat Lofthouse and two from Johnny Haynes . It was all to play for just prior to the second game .

This meant a victory was not necessary , and a 3 -- 3 draw at Wembley on 20 October 1961 would have been enough . England progressed to the final tournament , where they would be joined by their northern rivals . It was to be the last time Scotland took part in the World Cup until 1998 .

The Charter includes an implicit promise that the legislature will protect and respect the rights guaranteed and will not pass laws that violate the rights of Canadians . The courts are then given the authority to review laws passed by the Parliament or the provincial legislative assemblies and strike down parts that contradict the Charter rights . The judiciary also has the power to exclude evidence in trials, which comes from any source that violates the human rights of a person . However , the judiciary is under the instruction that it should attempt to preserve a balance between the protection of society by the laws , and the upholding of human rights of those being tried .

As with any Canadian federal law , the Charter comes into direct competition with those laws created by the provinces . However , the Charter does not apply to the territories directly .

The Charter does not explicitly give any power to Canadians to use in public petitions to the courts . According to sections 32.1 of the Charter , a person can petition the courts in the event where the Charter is being contravened and courts in turn decide if they have the jurisdiction to act if the dispute has arisen out of legislation . In the event the person , who has petitioned against the state , wins the case , section 32.1 of the Charter allows the courts to award any remedies they deem fit . The remedy that the courts normally award the petitioners of the Charter is a nominal financial amount of $1 . The nominal amount may be symbolic or may even serve to pay off legal expenses the petitioner incurred , but is often given so that a plaintiff has formally been `` awarded '' something and the legal case has not been futile . Some legal cases have ended with orders to pay $1 by the defendant . Section 32.1 also limits some aspects of the enforcement of the Charter , such that a Charter petitioner cannot be awarded a financial amount greater than $1 ,000 , unless the court finds that the violation of the Charter by the government was willful or has caused the petitioner harm .

The Charter is also not limited to the exercise of rights by adults . The Charter enforces the right that the rights in the Act be protected through legislation

Section 1 of the Charter states that the rights and freedoms that follow form an `` integral part of the Canadian law '' . This means they cannot be violated except under circumstances enumerated in the provisions on exceptions . Most rights in the Charter do not allow violations without justification . For example , before people can be arrested or jailed , evidence must be presented first before an independent judicial officer and must satisfy the threshold of `` probable cause '' . These rights and freedoms are enforceable , although other legal limitations might remain . On some issues ( for example , discrimination or sexual assault ) the issue was never resolved when the Act came into force . Judicial interpretations on these provisions are thus unknown . Thus , the Charter guarantees `` broad rights ''.

The Charter is not justiciable in Quebec because of section 33 ( the notwithstanding clause ) of the Charter . This section permits parliament and legislatures to exempt all of the Charter or some of its provisions from judicial review , by way of a formal vote . An exemption from judicial review lasts up to five years . There are many legal restrictions to the use of the notwithstanding clause , mainly designed to ensure it is used carefully . These restrictions are outlined in the legislation that enacted the clause, the Canada Act 1982 .

Some parts of the Charter are called `` remedial '' or `` protective '' . Courts are more likely to strike down inoperative laws or regulations and award remedies ( such as the remedy for damages ) to individuals who have suffered under laws passed by provincial or federal legislatures because the courts treat the rights in those sections as `` more deserving '' or `` more important '' . Other parts of the Charter carry no remedy with them and those rights are called `` negative rights '' .
